review_title: I've worked as a research assistant for most of my four years at Wellesley and loved it - my advisor is wonderful.

cons: Wellesley's administration isn't the best, and your experience will vary widely depending on whom you work with.

job_title: Knapp Media and Technology Center in Wellesley, MA
pros: Flexible hours, great work environment and management
cons: Sometimes must complete tasks unrelated to your job

pros: Um... hmm....Oh, I know!....when the weather is ok it's nice to walk around outside!....oh, and the museum can have interesting exhibits. Ahem.
cons:
What's the maximum word count allowed here? 

I'll just summarize... 

What they call "Leadership." I would have rather have worked for King Joffrey. In my twenty years of experience I've had several difficult bosses, but this was, by far, the unhappiest, most miserable, lowest, uninspiring, dead, micro-managing, controlling group of people I have ever worked for. I have spent way too much time thinking about the things I wish I had said to my boss. 

The buildings are Dickensian, as is the work culture, and I was the whipping boy.
I was chased in to a corner and reduced to groveling. My sadistic "boss" took pleasure in it, and when I reached out for help my hand was slapped. I had no support or help. After several years of abuse I reached out for help one final time and was suddenly terminated. The message?: Don't ask for help, don't complain, don't breathe. Don't ever ask for more porridge. Ever.

review_title: Very positive experience; gained many core skills and confidence.
job_title: Library and Technology Services (RIS) Student Consultant in Wellesley, MA
pros: Overall positive experience. It was a fun place to work and I miss it. The library staff are incredibly friendly, helpful, and show that they actually care. There were many opportunities for training and promotion and I really felt I gained an immense amount of skills and confidence. There was always a collaborate and team-oriented feel to working. I enjoyed my job, which can't be said of many places.
cons: More interaction between students and staff would help a great deal. When first starting as a new hire, it can be difficult to speak up and ask for help if not comfortable with those working around you on the same shift.

pros: Great benefits. Lots of time off available (although you might not be allowed to take it). Beautiful campus. Lots of support for additional training and learning new skillsets.
cons: Bureaucratic and stagnant to a ridiculous degree. Management does not listen to complaints and gives little support -- as a result morale is very low. Compensation (other than benefits) is also lower than the market. Opportunities for advancement are limited unless you can switch departments. Most talented staff seem to leave within a few years for better positions elsewhere and take a long time to be replaced.

review_title: Elitist with entitled and toxic student culture
pros:
Decent benefits
Had some warm colleagues
Beautiful campus
cons:
Lack of investment in their (non-tenured) faculty and staff while spending $$$ to upgrade buildings; cutting curriculum and staff by 10% despite having over a billion dollars in their endowment

Entitled, toxic students who simultaneously think the world revolves around them while also suffering from severe mental health concerns that the College does little to treat effectively (note the suicides that occur each year or two)

Overall elitist feel, not only from the campus but also the town of Wellesley (example: they look down at faculty for renting; many instances of racism experienced by my colleagues of color)

pros: Housing is included, good community, fun environment, there is a nurturing learning experience, you grow closer with professors and colleagues.
cons: If you live on campus without a car, it is difficult to go anywhere, including the grocery store if you need to provide your own food. While living on campus there is very little social interaction outside of work. Often, employers think that you will work outside of your normal hours because you live on campus.

pros: Beautiful campus, good benefits, some great co-workers, fantastic students.  Well respected college with a enviable endowment.
cons: Wellesley was a fantastic place to work when I first arrived.  However within the last 3 years there has been a mass exodus of administrative staff from all levels (from the top down), which has caused serious problems. Toxic supervisors, overworked staff, little support from HR. Given the workload and responsibility assigned to many administrators, pay is low.  Gross funding inequities between departments.

pros: Great school and academic community, beautiful campus. Good benefits and overall quality of life. Best if you work in a smaller, somewhat independent department. Wonderful cultural opportunities, like lectures, art exhibits, music and theater performances.
cons: Very silo-ed and hierarchical administrative structure. Low salary scale. It's a little out of the way, and getting there via mass transit is very difficult, so you need a car.

pros:
Great office dynamic. 
The counselors are always incredibly nice.
You get the opportunity to help students that come into the office all the time.
You learn the ins and outs of the CWS and you get to learn a lot about the opportunities CWS can offer.
cons: A bit disorganized at first, but that was because we didn't have a director for a semester. But that should be getting better with the new director and I'm sure the new changes will be awesome!

job_title: LGBTQ Events and Programs Assistant in Wellesley, MA
pros: As far as work-study jobs go, this one is fairly easy.
cons: Work-life balance was awful not because we were overworked, but drastically underworked, as the office of intercultural education over-hires far more people than needed in order to not overwork us, with the end result that each student employee works only a few hours a semester.

pros: elastic working hours, student friendly working environment, does not require many work experience, people, coworkers are helpful.
cons: minimum payment, limited job openings, working options not available all through out the year, summer working hours extremely limited

review_title: Good students, but employees should be treated better
pros:
- Students are smart and hard-working. 
- Teaching load is reasonable.
- Monetary support for research is good.
- Campus is gorgeous. College has a lot of resources for its size.
cons:
- Not enough administrative support. Admins seem overworked and faculty are expected to do most admin work ourselves.
- Not enough collegiality or opportunities for social interaction.
- Hierarchies and politics within and between departments.

pros: Gorgeous physical environment.  Rigorous yet nurturing & collegial atmosphere.  Dedicated faculty/staff/students.  Wonderful traditions.  Surprisingly diverse student body.
cons: Outdated technology, little money for research due to emphasis on teaching.

review_title: Great place to work while you are a student there!
pros: Wellesley is full of nice and compassionate employees.  I felt valued and like I made a difference, even though I was a student and only worked part-time.
cons: There aren't too many downsides that I can think of.  The pay is not amazing, but when you are a student it is not a bad option.

pros: A great opportunity for undergraduates who want science research experiences. Most projects do not have a lot of prerequisites as well.
cons: The compensation is lower than most of the summer research programs, but good enough!

job_title: General Cook/General Service Worker in Roxbury, MA
pros: Pays very well, Always room to grow in culinary or any job field on campus.
cons: Seasonal work. No unemployment while you are laid off, when school is on break.

pros: Not bad for a student worker, pretty much what you would expect. They're pretty flexible about accommodating to your schedule.
cons: No growth potential, work isn't very interesting as a student assistant. But you'd be hard pressed to find a more flexible/accommodating schedule.

pros: Inspired vision, mission, the opportunity to work with brilliant and creative colleagues
cons: change of president and student life dean- suddenly working under an administration that was not on board with our team mission

review_title: Great Way to Get Laboratory Experience While In School
pros: Lots of attention & guidance from your PI, Great experiences learning the ropes, Trusted w a lot of responsibility bc there are very few post-docs
cons: No cons that I can think of

review_title: Good place if you're not looking to move up
pros: Safe and beautiful campus; summer hours; followed the school's holiday schedule
cons: Budget cuts were painful; promotions either took forever or never happened; management all about the business and not about their employees

pros: If you are a student at Wellesley, it's a better place to work than any alternative. Choose your own hours, bosses were always kind
cons: Minimum wage, but that's very high in Mass. Many jobs work business hours only

job_title: Social Media Marketing in Wellesley Hills, MA
pros: flexible hours, good work atmosphere
cons: bureaucracy, very high turnover, no advancement

pros: Excellent salary and benefits, even for part-time lecturers (3-5 classes per semester).  Strong students.  Friendly, inclusive atmosphere.
cons: Students can be a bit entitled at time (demand extra office hours, practice problems, etc.).

the people want you to succeed and are so supportive
location is beautiful
work is substantive
paid internship

pros: Intellectually curious students. Beautiful campus. Incredible facilities.
cons: Students are usually stressed out and have a hard time thinking outside of the box because of the academic standards and structure.

pros: Really fun and supportive team at Career Education
cons: I have nothing negative to say, I've had a lovely time working at Career Education.
